item.title: Photo Essay
item.dc:creator: Ian Beilfuss
item.link: https://ian88.github.io/photos/Photo Essay - Behold the Wisconsin State Capitol/
item.description:
This photo essay was created for the course Documentary Photography for the Sciences at UW-Madison to practice building a compelling narrative to accompany my photography. The photo essay captures the grandeur and history of the Wisconsin State Capitol. View the photo essay below or click to view in its original PDF format

Behold: The Wisconsin State Capitol

Located at the heart of Madison, the Wisconsin State Capitol is one of the most iconic capitol buildings in the United States. Standing atop the Capitol is a 15’5” gilded bronze statue Wisconsin, created by the same sculpture that made the Abraham Lincoln statue in the Lincoln Memorial. In front of the Capitol, Forward stands proudly, symbolizing the State motto of “Forward” and commemorating the women’s suffrage movement

Welcome In!

The grandeur of the State Capitol is immediately present upon walking in. Built in 1917 after the previous capitol building burned to the ground, the Capitol has stood proud as a symbol for history, architecture, and governance for over 100 years

The West Gallery

The West Gallery of the Capitol is home to the State Assembly Chambers. A badger, the Wisconsin State Animal can be seen overlooking the gallery

Largest Dome in the USA

Wisconsin State Capitol boasts the largest dome by volume of any Capitol in the United States, including the National Capitol. Made of granite, the only one in the United States, the dome rises 284 feet above the ground and is the tallest point in Madison

Incricacies Everywhere

Detailed carvings are present throughout the Capitol building, adding beauty and complexity to the grandeur of the atrium

Scavenger Hunt

The Capitol uses over 30 types of marble, sourced from seven states, three European countries, and one African country. Incased in the marble are fossil remains from the Precambrian age, like the starfish in this image. Visit and see if you can find the starfish, coral, nautiloid, gastropod, and others!

Curious? Learn More!

Curious about the Capitol and want to learn more about its history, architecture, and governance? The Capitol offers free 45- minute guided tours Mondays through Saturday at 9 am, 10 am, 11 am, 1 pm, 2 pm, and 3 pm, and Sundays at 1 pm, 2 pm, and 3 pm. There’s also a free museum on the 6th floor discussing the history of the Capitol. You can learn more by clicking here
item.guid: https://ian88.github.io/photos/Photo Essay - Behold the Wisconsin State Capitol/

item.title: Photo Essay
item.dc:creator: Ian Beilfuss
item.link: https://ian88.github.io/photos/Photo Essay - Reed Turchi Live at Rosa’s Lounge/
item.description:
This photo essay was created for the course Documentary Photography for the Sciences at UW-Madison to practice building a compelling narrative to accompany my photography. The photo essay captures my experience watching my cousin’s band perform at Rosa’s Lounge in Chicago. View the photo essay below or click to view in its original PDF format

Reed Turchi Live at Rosa’s Lounge

Reed Turchi, one of the top blues musicians in the US (and my cousin), jamming out at the last venue on the tour for his latest album, World on Fire

Welcome to Rosa’s

For over 45 years Rosa’s Lounge has hosted some the top blues artists in the nation, with live shows seven days a week

Tuning Up

Properly turned instruments are essential for a great show

Ready for the Blues

Reed’s guitar, the centerpiece of the show, is ready for action

Boom Boom Pow

The drumkit lies in wait, moments before the start of the show

And We’re Live

Reed Turchi and his band take the stage to play their hearts out

Man of the Hour

Reed Turchi takes slide guitar blues to the next level

Movin’ and Groovin’

Some music is just too good to stay seated; the blues just makes you wanna dance. What a way to end the final show of the tour
item.guid: https://ian88.github.io/photos/Photo Essay - Reed Turchi Live at Rosa’s Lounge/
